hints: One of Earth's large landmasses
There are typically seven recognized ones
Asia is the largest example
A vast body of saltwater
Covers most of Earth's surface
The Pacific is the largest
A piece of land surrounded by water
Smaller than a continent
Greenland is the largest example
A piece of land almost surrounded by water but connected to the mainland on one side
Florida is a famous example
The Arabian one is the largest
A group or chain of islands
Indonesia is a country made of many of these
The Hawaiian Islands form one
A large body of still water surrounded by land
Can be freshwater or saltwater
Baikal is the deepest example
A large natural stream of water flowing in a channel to the sea, a lake, or another stream
The Nile is the longest example
Often used for transportation
A large natural elevation of the Earth's surface
Taller than a hill
Everest is the highest example
A low area of land between hills or mountains
Often has a river or stream running through it
The Grand Canyon is a famous example
A large area of flat land elevated high above sea level
Also known as a high plain or tableland
The Tibetan one is the highest and largest
A large area of flat land with few trees
Often used for agriculture
The Great Plains of North America are an example
A barren or desolate area of land
Receives very little precipitation
The Sahara is the largest hot example
A slowly moving mass or river of ice
Formed by the accumulation and compaction of snow
Found in polar regions and high mountains
A mountain or hill having a crater or vent through which lava, rock fragments, hot vapor, and gas are being or have been erupted
Mount Vesuvius is a famous example
Can be active, dormant, or extinct
A deep gorge, typically one with a river flowing through it
Often has steep sides
The Grand Canyon is a prime example
A natural underground chamber or series of chambers
Mammoth Cave is the longest known system
Often formed by water erosion
A steep rock face, especially at the edge of the sea
The Cliffs of Moher are famous
Often formed by erosion
A long, narrow, deep inlet of the sea between high cliffs
Typically formed by glacial erosion
Common in Norway and New Zealand
A hot spring in which water intermittently boils, sending a tall column of water and steam into the air
Old Faithful in Yellowstone is a famous one
Found in volcanic areas
A fertile spot in a desert where water is found
Often has palm trees
A place of refuge in arid lands
A mound or ridge of sand or other loose sediment formed by the wind
Common in deserts and on coastlines
Can be crescent-shaped or linear
A vast, flat, treeless Arctic region of Europe, Asia, and North America
The ground is permanently frozen (permafrost)
A type of cold desert biome
A dense forest characterized by high rainfall
Found in tropical regions
The Amazon is the largest example
A grassland ecosystem characterized by grasses and scattered trees
Found in tropical and subtropical regions
Common in Africa
A large area of flat grassland with no trees
Found in Eastern Europe and Central Asia
A drier grassland than savanna
An area of low-lying land that is flooded in wet seasons or at high tide
Typically remains waterlogged at all times
A type of wetland
A wetland that is forested
Often characterized by trees and woody plants
The Everglades are a famous example
A wetland characterized by spongy, acidic peat deposits
Often covered with mosses
A type of mire
A landform that is formed at the mouth of a river
Where the river deposits sediment as it enters a larger body of water
The Nile River has a famous one
The tidal mouth of a large river
Where the tide meets the stream
A partially enclosed coastal body of brackish water
A broad inlet of the sea where the land curves inward
Smaller than a gulf
The Bay of Fundy is known for its high tides
A deep inlet of the sea almost surrounded by land, with a narrow mouth
Larger than a bay
The Gulf of Mexico is a famous example
A narrow passage of water connecting two seas or two large areas of water
The Strait of Gibraltar connects the Atlantic and Mediterranean
Often strategically important
A length of water wider than a strait, joining two larger areas of water
The English Channel separates England and France
Can also refer to a river or stream bed
A shallow body of water separated from a larger body of water by a barrier
Often found along coastlines or within atolls
Bora Bora has a famous one
A ring-shaped coral reef or island
Encloses a lagoon
Formed from submerged volcanic islands
A ridge of rocks, sand, or coral near the surface of the water
The Great Barrier Reef is the largest example
Can be a hazard to navigation
A marine invertebrate that forms colonies
Builds reefs in warm, shallow ocean waters
Often brightly colored
Unsorted glacial sediment
Deposited directly by a glacier
Forms moraines
A mass of rocks and sediment carried down and deposited by a glacier
Can be lateral, medial, or terminal
Forms distinct ridges or mounds
A half-open, steep-sided hollow at the head of a valley or on a mountainside
Formed by glacial erosion
Often contains a tarn (mountain lake)
A sharp, knife-like ridge
Formed by two glaciers eroding parallel valleys
Found in glaciated mountain regions
A sharp, pyramid-shaped peak
Formed by glacial erosion from multiple sides
The Matterhorn is a famous example
A valley with a distinctive cross-sectional shape
Formed by glacial erosion
Also known as a glacial trough
A valley with a distinctive cross-sectional shape
Formed by river erosion
Common in youthful landscapes
A U-shaped lake that forms when a wide meander of a river is cut off
Forms a free-standing body of water
Common in floodplains
A winding curve or bend in a river
Formed by erosion and deposition
Can lead to the formation of oxbow lakes
A flat land area adjacent to a river
Formed by the deposition of sediment during floods
Often very fertile
A natural or artificial embankment alongside a river
Prevents flooding
Can be built by humans or formed naturally
A fan-shaped deposit of sediment
Formed by flowing water at the base of a mountain
Common in arid regions
A natural depression in the surface of the land
Often collects water or sediment
The Great Basin in the US is an example
A large bowl-shaped hollow
Typically formed by the impact of a meteorite or the explosion of a volcano
Crater Lake is a famous example
A large volcanic crater
Formed by the collapse of a volcano's magma chamber
Larger than a typical crater
Molten rock that flows from a volcano or fissure
Cools and solidifies to form igneous rock
Can create new land
Molten rock found beneath the Earth's surface
Stored in a magma chamber
Becomes lava when it erupts
An opening in the Earth's crust
Through which volcanic materials are erupted
Part of a volcano
A long, narrow opening or crack in the Earth's surface
Can be a source of volcanic eruptions
Also known as a crack or crevice
A fracture or zone of fractures between two blocks of rock
Where earthquakes occur
The San Andreas is a famous example
A sudden and violent shaking of the ground
Caused by movements within the Earth's crust or volcanic action
Measured by the Richter scale
A long, high sea wave caused by an earthquake, submarine landslide, or other disturbance
Can cause widespread destruction in coastal areas
Japanese word for 'harbor wave'
The process of eroding or being eroded by wind, water, or other natural agents
Shapes landforms over time
Creates canyons and valleys
The process of breaking down rocks, soils, and minerals
Can be physical, chemical, or biological
Occurs in situ (in place)
The process by which sediment is added to a landform or landmass
Opposite of erosion
Forms deltas and floodplains
Matter that settles to the bottom of a liquid
Carried by wind, water, or ice
Forms sedimentary rocks
The outermost solid layer of the Earth
Divided into tectonic plates
Where we live
The layer of the Earth between the crust and the outer core
Composed of hot, dense, solid rock
Convection currents here drive plate tectonics
The innermost layer of the Earth
Divided into an outer liquid part and an inner solid part
Composed mainly of iron and nickel
The theory that Earth's outer shell is divided into several large slabs
These slabs glide over the mantle
Explains earthquakes, volcanoes, and mountain building
A type of plate boundary
Where two tectonic plates move towards each other
Can form mountains or subduction zones
A type of plate boundary
Where two tectonic plates move away from each other
Forms mid-ocean ridges and rift valleys
A type of plate boundary
Where two tectonic plates slide past each other horizontally
Causes earthquakes but no volcanism
An area where one tectonic plate slides under another
Often forms oceanic trenches and volcanic arcs
Associated with convergent boundaries
A linear-shaped lowland between several highlands or mountain ranges
Created by the action of a geologic rift or fault
The East African one is famous
An underwater mountain range
Formed by plate tectonics at a divergent boundary
The Mid-Atlantic Ridge is an example
A long, narrow, deep depression in the ocean floor
Formed by subduction zones
The Mariana is the deepest
A mountain rising from the ocean seafloor that does not reach to the water's surface
Typically formed from extinct volcanoes
An underwater mountain
A flat or gently sloping underwater plain
Found at depths of 3,000 to 6,000 meters
Covers more than 50% of the Earth's surface
The edge of a continent that lies under the ocean
Relatively shallow water
Rich in marine life
The steep slope that extends from the edge of the continental shelf down to the abyssal plain
Marks the true edge of the continent
Much steeper than the shelf
A large depression in the ocean floor
Contains the abyssal plains, trenches, and mid-ocean ridges
The Pacific Ocean has the largest one
An imaginary line drawn around the Earth equally distant from both poles
Divides the Earth into Northern and Southern Hemispheres
Zero degrees latitude
The angular distance of a place north or south of the Earth's equator
Measured in degrees
Lines run horizontally on a map
The angular distance of a place east or west of the prime meridian
Measured in degrees
Lines run vertically on a map
A circle of constant longitude passing through a given place on the Earth's surface and the terrestrial poles
The Prime Meridian is the most famous
Lines run from pole to pole
A circle of latitude on the Earth's surface
Runs parallel to the equator
Lines run horizontally on a map
Half of the Earth
Can be Northern, Southern, Eastern, or Western
Divided by the Equator or Prime Meridian
The most northerly circle of latitude on Earth
Where the sun is directly overhead at the summer solstice
Located at 23.5 degrees North
The most southerly circle of latitude on Earth
Where the sun is directly overhead at the winter solstice
Located at 23.5 degrees South
The most northerly of the five major circles of latitude
Marks the region where the sun doesn't set during summer solstice
Located at 66.5 degrees North
The most southerly of the five major circles of latitude
Marks the region where the sun doesn't rise during winter solstice
Located at 66.5 degrees South
Either of the two points on the Earth's surface at the extremities of its axis of rotation
North and South are the two main ones
Covered in ice
The envelope of gases surrounding the Earth or another planet
Composed mainly of nitrogen and oxygen
Protects life on Earth
The lowest region of the atmosphere
Where most weather occurs
Extends from the Earth's surface to about 12 km
The layer of the Earth's atmosphere above the troposphere
Contains the ozone layer
Extends from about 12 km to 50 km
The layer of the Earth's atmosphere above the stratosphere
Where most meteors burn up
Extends from about 50 km to 85 km
The layer of the Earth's atmosphere above the mesosphere
Where the aurora occurs
Extends from about 85 km to 600 km
The outermost region of a planet's atmosphere
Where the atmosphere thins out into space
Extends from about 600 km to 10,000 km
A layer in the Earth's stratosphere
Absorbs most of the Sun's ultraviolet radiation
Protects life on Earth
A natural electrical phenomenon characterized by the appearance of streamers of reddish or greenish light in the sky
Also known as the Northern or Southern Lights
Occurs in the thermosphere
A seasonal prevailing wind in the region of South and Southeast Asia
Brings heavy rainfall
A major weather pattern
A tropical cyclone with sustained winds of 74 miles per hour or greater
Forms over warm ocean waters
Known as a typhoon in the western Pacific
A tropical cyclone occurring in the region of the Philippines or the China Sea
Another name for a hurricane in the Pacific
A powerful rotating storm
A violently rotating column of air extending from a thunderstorm to the ground
Known for its destructive power
Often forms in 'Tornado Alley' in the US
A severe snowstorm with high winds and low visibility
Characterized by heavy snowfall and strong winds
A type of winter storm
A prolonged period of abnormally low rainfall
Leads to a shortage of water
Can cause widespread crop failure
An overflow of a large amount of water beyond its normal limits
Can be caused by heavy rain or melting snow
A natural disaster
The long-term average weather pattern in a region
Includes temperature, precipitation, and wind
Different from weather
The state of the atmosphere at a place and time
Includes temperature, precipitation, and wind
Changes day to day
A large naturally occurring community of flora and fauna occupying a major habitat
Examples include rainforest, desert, and tundra
Defined by climate and vegetation
A biological community of interacting organisms and their physical environment
Includes living and non-living components
A smaller unit than a biome
The natural home or environment of an animal, plant, or other organism
Provides food, water, and shelter
Can be a forest, desert, or ocean
The variety of life in the world or in a particular habitat or ecosystem
Includes genetic, species, and ecosystem diversity
High in rainforests
The protection of animals, plants, and natural resources
A key goal in geography and environmental science
Aims to preserve biodiversity
The clearing of forests for other land use
A major environmental issue
Contributes to climate change
The process by which fertile land becomes desert
Caused by drought, deforestation, and unsustainable agriculture
A major environmental problem
A gradual increase in the overall temperature of the Earth's atmosphere
Attributed to the greenhouse effect
A major climate change concern
The trapping of the sun's warmth in a planet's lower atmosphere
Caused by certain gases
Contributes to global warming
The total amount of greenhouse gases produced by an individual, event, organization, or product
Expressed as carbon dioxide equivalent
A measure of environmental impact
The ability to be maintained at a certain rate or level
Meeting the needs of the present without compromising the ability of future generations to meet their own needs
A key concept in environmental geography
The process by which towns and cities are formed and become larger
A global trend
Leads to increased population density in cities
Relating to or characteristic of the countryside rather than the town
Opposite of urban
Often associated with agriculture
The number of people per unit of area
Often measured in people per square kilometer or mile
High in cities, low in deserts
The movement of people from one place to another
Can be internal or international
Often driven by economic or environmental factors
The study of statistics such as births, deaths, income, or the incidence of disease
Illustrates the changing structure of human populations
A branch of geography
The science or practice of drawing maps
A fundamental skill in geography
Involves projection and scale
A system used to transfer locations from Earth's surface to a flat map
Always involves some distortion
Mercator is a famous example
The ratio between the distance on a map and the corresponding distance on the ground
Can be large or small
Indicates the level of detail on a map
A key to the symbols and colors used on a map
Helps interpret map features
Also known as a map key
A figure on a map, chart, or plan
Used to display the orientation of the cardinal directions
Shows North, South, East, and West
A network of lines on a map
Used to locate points by means of coordinates

The arrangement of the natural and artificial physical features of an area
Includes elevation, relief, and landforms
Often shown on a topographic map
The height of a place above sea level
Often measured in meters or feet
Shown on topographic maps
The difference in elevation between the highest and lowest points in a particular area
Describes the shape of the land surface
High in mountains, low in plains
A line on a topographic map connecting points of equal elevation
Shows the shape and slope of the land
Closely spaced lines indicate steep slopes
An area or ridge of land that separates waters flowing to different rivers, basins, or seas

All water within it drains to a common outlet
A high point or ridge that separates two drainage basins

A river or stream flowing into a larger river or lake
Contributes water to the main river system

A stream that branches off and flows away from a main river
Common in river deltas
Opposite of a tributary

The beginning of a river
The place where a river enters a sea, lake, or larger river

The end of a river

The boundary between land and sea
Can be rocky, sandy, or marshy
The line where a body of water meets the land

A specific point on the coast
A gently sloping shore of a body of water
Covered by sand or pebbles
A popular recreational area
A mound of sand formed by the wind
Found on beaches and in deserts
Can migrate over time
A narrow point of land projecting into the sea
Formed by the deposition of sediment by longshore drift
A coastal landform
A bar of sand or shingle joining an island to the mainland
Formed by deposition
Connects an island to the coast
A long, narrow island running parallel to the coastline

Often found along the East Coast of the US
A narrow piece of land that projects from a coastline into the sea

A small, sheltered bay or inlet

A secluded coastal feature
A large sea or ocean inlet larger than a bay
Typically deeper than a bay

A city or town with a harbor where ships load or unload
A center for trade and commerce

A piece of land almost surrounded by water but connected to the mainland on one side

A narrow strip of land connecting two larger land areas
Has water on two sides
The Isthmus of Panama connects North and South America
A high point of land that extends into a body of water

A point of high land that juts out into a large body of water
Similar to a cape or headland

Plural for steep rock faces
Often found along coastlines or in canyons

A long, steep slope, especially one at the edge of a plateau or separating areas of land at different heights

A type of cliff

Spanish for 'table'

Similar to a hogback but less steep

Pillar-like rock formations

When the surface of a lava flow solidifies but the interior remains molten

Beneath the surface of the Earth

Fine particles of rock and volcanic glass
Ejected during a volcanic eruption

A siliceous or calcareous deposit
Formed by mineral springs

Heat energy generated and stored in the Earth

Used for electricity generation and heating
Relating to or denoting the action of heated water in the Earth's crust

The remains or impression of a prehistoric plant or animal embedded in rock

The science that deals with the Earth's physical structure and substance
Its history, and the processes that act on it
A branch of Earth science
The study of the Earth's physical features and atmosphere
And of human activity as it affects and is affected by these
The subject of this game

Shows both natural and man-made features

Has cardinal directions

Shows precipitation patterns

Where true north and magnetic north align
